content: alberta summer by sandra buzza this is a lightweight pullover perfect for the cool summer evenings in alberta my samples were made with rustic yarns custom woolens single ply for the grey sample and custom woolens 2 ply sock yarn for the dark pink sample however this pattern will work well for most fingering weight yarns and most fibres it s meant to fit like your favourite weekend sweatshirt so leave 2 to 6 inches of positive ease this is a good project for a beginner sweater knitter as the lace is very simple and there s minimal shaping german short row are used to lower the front neckline materials yarn 3 skeins of custom woolens mule spinner single ply yarn or sock yarn or 1000 1050 1150 1250 m of fingering weight yarn needle 3 25mm us 3 circular needle for the ribbing and a 3 75mm us 5 circular needle for the body of the sweater you can vary the wire length to accommodate the number of stitches or use a longer wire and use magic looping for the sleeves and neckline gauge 24 sts and 36 row for 4 or 19 cm in stockinette after blocking sizes s m l xl giving a finished chest measurement of 38 42 45 1/2 49 the body and sleeves measure 13 5 or 34 cm for all sizes measured from the underarm but can be easily adjusted make sure to add extra yarn for lengthening garment the back hem is 2 or 5cm longer than the front german short row german short row are used the raise the back neckline and lower the back hemline in this sweater they are indicated in the pattern by the term ds which stands for double stitch to do this right side work to the stitch specified in your pattern and turn the work so the wrong side is facing slip the first stitch on the left needle to the right needle purlwise with yarn in front pull the yarn to the back of the work over top of the right needle this will distort the stitch making it look as if there are 2 stitches instead of 1 bring the yarn to the front again between the needles to begin purling make sure to keep firm gauge on this double stitch when purling the next stitch wrong side purl to the stitch indicated by the pattern and turn the work so the right side is facing bring the yarn to the front between the needle and slip the first stitch from the left needle to the right needle purlwise with the yarn in front pull the yarn to the back of the work over top of the right needle this will distort the stitch
